author: BatMeckley
content:
Without going too therapist couch on the details, I was the only kid that had to lie to my parents in highschool and tell them I was going to parties (which were ok) and then went to work playing shows on the sunset strip (which was banned). Moving to Australia to join a band in my early 20s got me excommunicated from half of my family, some of whom I didn’t get to talk to for nearly a decade. Some had credible experience in the industry, others just in life, but truthfully, if you care about someone’s quality of life and ability to provide for themselves and hopefully a family, you don’t steer them towards a career in music. 

But, I wouldn’t be told no, and every time I was pushed away from something I wanted to do (I couldn’t go to school in LA because it was too close to the industry) I ended up somewhere that actually furthered my career (I ended up in San Diego, where I became friends with the Switchfoot guys which really helped launch me). It’s why I have such little patience for the “oh the studio manager was short with me while I was an assistant” crowd… if you want it bad enough, you figure out a way to make it work. And if you don’t want it bad enough, there’s a hundred more guys like me that do, that are willing to sacrifice their time/health/money/etc to the cause. I don’t say that to frame it as admirable or healthy or anything positive, it’s just the truth of how things are. 

So, that person that’s going to quit because a studio manager was challenging, or a teacher didn’t like their song? They’re going to get devoured by the people that really dedicate their lives to this, and it feels cruel to tell them otherwise.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Hey folks, back from mix with the masters with Jon & Teezio. I wanted to share just a little bit in case anyone else here is considering attending a workshop in the future. I was initially on the fence, but am very glad I went. 

Jon & Teezio were amazing together. I don't know how often MWTM does workshops with two engineers, but it really enriched the experience for me. It was actually comical how different their perspectives were on mixing, the business side, motivation for the work, lifestyle, etc... This created fascinating debate / conversation in the group. The Grammy nominations were announced while we were all together and we got to celebrate Jon & Teezio as a group for their I think combined 6 or 7 nominations. They brought in a bucket of champaign. All this after having gone through the sessions for said grammy nominated work earlier in the week. 10 / 10.

Rue Boyer studios is actually insane. Probably the best room I've been in.

There were attendees from all over the world. We ended up sharing mixes and receiving feedback from J&T. Hearing and sharing records in the same room with the people who made them with context provided from varying countries, cultures, genres, and scenes was as enlightening a music listening experience as I'm likely to have for the rest of my life.

So if anyone else here is on the fence in the future. Here's a tiny nudge.

author: bobby k
content: sort of related, but i've been reflecting a lot on how precious it is to maintain a listener's perspective on a work in progress, and what things we can be doing as the producer/mixer/etc to grant that privilege to the artist first and foremost. the simple stuff includes saving the nitty gritty work for your own time, delivering the best mix of the record no matter the stage it's in, focusing any time spent together on how you can make their voice and contributions and ideas the best they can be. some artists love mixing and editing and getting into the weeds, but i'm realizing quite often how much of a duty it is to be the artist, and how record making is only a single slice of that pie. For us it is more or less the whole pie. and a big responsibility we carry (perhaps without realizing?) is that it is our job to protect the artist from getting  stressed out by the process. and this extends to processing and managing our own stress about the work should it exist, as stress is a contagious energy.

author: kieronmenzies
content: On the topic of communication, I know it goes without saying (pretty sure we're all guilty of this) but it's always worth mentioning in case there are any younger impressionable minds reading this. Older unimpressionable minds may as well read it too. Don't forget to communicate with yourself. Week in and week out, I don't know how many times I plug my ears and go "lalala I'm not listening" when my body starts throwing terms at me like fatigue, exhaustion, dehydrated, hungry, getting sick, underslept, stressed, depressed, fully sick, too much coffee, etc. At this point, maybe it's time to listen and do yourself a favor because in the long run, every favor done for you is also a favor to your family, your community and your clients.

author: popaganda.
content: Also remember/understand that the fear of not making it can quickly switch to the overwhelming weight of being expected to be excellent all the time. At the end of the day we need to take care of ourselves and each other, no matter where we are in the game.

author: bobby k
content: In the midst of a kinda unique side quest at the moment - label pulls me in at an hourly rate with an artist (and good friend) that I’ve mixed for many times because the production sessions were such a mess that they felt like they couldn’t even finish the records until some light mixing and organization took place. Songs spread out between multiple project files, DAWs, laptops…vocals tracked to mp3s with the ~50ms delay thing…Some of these producers templates…brilliant stuff. Saw one vocal travel through maybe 7 or 8 auxes and hit probably 4 different rvox’s along the way. It was like a labyrinth of signal flow that was nearly impossible to follow (and once I deleted half the auxes and waves plugins, it started to come back to life). In short they’re having me un-mix it, hand it back for some more production, then do the final mixes later this year. A true testament to the importance of organization and more importantly minimalist, straight forward session files. I wonder how often this need comes up and how feasible it is to be involved ahead of the handoff as a mixer these days. And before you frown at me for griping, this is an absolutely incredible project, many insanely talented musicians I respect. Very right brained, free flowing group. So it felt cool to be able to play more of a part on the project as the more left brained participant and see the stress relief happen in real time.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
We all want our work to be undeniable, but the only way for most of us to get there is to slog through it. 

The music industry has an uncanny ability to burn out the chaff- passing vanity and a belief that somehow you’re special is just not enough to keep you going in the dark times. And most of the times are dark, my friends. 

But the upshot is, most of the folks I came up with that stuck with it are doing really cool shit now. A lot of my heroes have become friends. I’ve done a lot of cool bucket list type shit. And truly it’s not cause I myself am undeniable, it’s cause I slogged through.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hey @everyone. A quick PSA about form on this server: 

As this server becomes more populated the quantity of daily/hourly posts are increasing. This is a great development and we love to see lively, thoughtful conversations. 

With this increase in posting comes a lot of information that can sometimes be overwhelming to manage and parse. Especially when a channel has two different conversations happening on top of each other. I think we've all casually opened the app at one point and seen "40+ unread messages" and been taken aback by the sheer amount of convo that we now have to catch up on.

Moving forward I ask the following from everyone:

*1. If you see a conversation starting to ramp up use Discord’s **Create Thread** feature to fork off the conversation into a self-contained thread. (see attached pic)
2. Give the thread a descriptive name.
3. Continue all follow-up posts within the new thread.*

author: BatMeckley
content: I feel like virtually all of us are dealing with mental health issues in one way or the other. For me, getting out of my own way is not over analyzing every step I take and re-litigating every mix decision to the point where I end up only releasing a handful of songs every few years.  At some point, no matter what our individual issues are, we have to log off the internet and actually make music instead of constantly talking about all of the individual reasons why we can’t. Sometimes, at least in my case, we get analysis paralysis because it’s easier than actually hitting record and just doing the damn thing. There was this meme going around last week that was something along the line of “oh hey task that only took me 15 minutes but I’ve been putting off for 5 months”. I think we can all get caught up in bathing in the 58 reasons why we can’t do something instead of just locking on to the few reasons we can, because it’s safer to live in our potential than our actual.

author: cian riordan
content:
"Sorry about the late night duplicate file, I did this track after six other people because I'm rushing as a team player.   I delivered as promised up front as we are all in overtime now to make it great.  *CLIENT* is happy with your work and with mine and we are all working overtime together.   Apologies also, I know there were some annoying ticks in there with some of the revised files. Still not sure why this one session did that. 

Of course I don't listen to every single file, post rendering.   We render and send 500-1000 files a month with the revisions on the 200-300 monthly songs that I do.  Team players don't ask such things on CC.  I work usually 7 days a week for 40-50 people a month, and making them happy with great masters is job #1.  Perfectionism is not a part of that process.    Software makes mistake, and that's ok.    People make mistakes and that's ok.   Mixes and masters should never aim for perfect, they should aim to connect, aim for humanity.  

Perfection is not the goal here, it's musicality and teamwork.  I'm sorry your ears suffered that horrible popping, but please, be cool. "

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Imposter syndrome is normal and good. 

Just accept it and realize that some anxiety about your abilities will continue to push you to do better work.

Find mental health strategies so it doesn't drive you insane.

People who always think they're great or have it all figured out never improve and generally start to make shitty work quickly.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I happily worked from home for two solid years, very focused and disciplined. I was doing maybe 2-7 days a month engineering in commercial studios as well, so that kept my *being in the room with people and making shit happen in the moment* side satisfied.

In terms of getting work done, home was great, I had more time to use exercising and cooking. Moving to a mix room away from home turned out to have a much greater positive effect on my mental health than I thought though, and now I don’t know if I could go back. It’s really helped me separate work from life (even though I still routinely wake up thinking about work), and I much prefer co-writing there as it’s a real sanctuary.

Finance-wise, it’s certainly taking a chunk. The dream longer term is to have an amazing, amazing shed in a back garden, within commutable distance to London/major music hub… just like everyone else in their 30s here.

author: oaklandmatt
content: Your brain has all these wonderful ways of avoiding difficult things. This is because if you dealt with them all at once, it would overwhelm you. So the brain builds all these mechanisms and habits to help you survive. Therapy, meditation, self reflection, but most importantly *other people that you trust and can be vulnerable around* can help you get through barriers that your own brain has created

author: cian riordan
content:
In the studio, this was like getting a golden ticket. It turns out, there’s no shortcut to greatness. You have to put in the work. Want to get a great drum sound? Do the work. Pick out the right drums. Spend time tuning them. Put them in the right place in the room. Try different places in the room. Try different drums. Setup some microphones. Listen. Adjust. Move the microphones. Maybe change the drums. Maybe change the microphones. Maybe they don't sound good because the part isn’t right? Maybe it's something else in the arrangement? Take it out. Try it. 

This takes quite a bit of motivation to get this deep in the weeds. But the results? Well, they were always unquestionably great. Could it have been fine with less work? Maybe. But you’d never know. And nobody is going to care about this record more than you are.

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s tricky, it’s a bit how I was saying the old head front of house guy was probably underselling his knowledge. 

There is a friend of mine that’s
worked on some massive records, and they did a bunch of interviews and tik toks about all of the work and automation and plugins and processing that it took to make the record sound great, and while they work a ton, it always struck me that if I was the artist I would be hesitant to work with such a “look how responsible _I_ am for the end product” producer. 

I’ve always tried to come from the perspective of whenever I’m asked about a record I’ve worked on with “man, the artist just sounds like that in the room, I was just lucky to be there and try and capture the magic” 

It’s not an apples to apples comparison with Rubin, but benefit of the doubt style MAYBE there’s a bit of that in there? I’ve always thought the kids just want to believe the person on the poster is the genius. They don’t need to know an 40 yo married couple wrote Sk8r Boi.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Couple ways I see this:
1) art is never completed, merely abandoned.

2) no one is actually a perfectionist, as evidence by nothing they have done is perfect. Guaranteed.

3) I think it is far more comforting to judge our work by the potential, vs the actual. When you actually release a piece of work it is now out there to be consumed, enjoyed, criticized, evaluated. It’s so much easier to just have this amorphous concept of an in progress piece of work, because it can be as grand and as loved as you can imagine in your head.

author: Deleted User
content:
what are some things that you’ve been wanting to do outside of work life? 

I feel like the idea of “break” can look and feel different to many people, and I think the key is to find what version of those variations give you the most peace of mind and self acceptance. 

Personally, I have a few tendencies and mindsets around break that self-sabotages. things I listed below help me fight the self-sabotaging

1) going armadillo- when in extreme overwhelming state, you gotta find a way to get out of that. I get overwhelmed very easily, so I find that this is often needed. BUT, if you’re gonna go armadillo, then you wanna really commit to it until you feel a bit calmer and collected. Which leads to the next point 

2) sometimes I lie to myself that I’m taking a break but do a few spurts of work because I feel useless not doing work. I’ve learned that this needs to be avoided or else the “break” will be extended into a longer period of time, and I’d be doing little work here and there but also not get anything done properly. It takes a bit of commitment to take a proper break, and in order  to be able to commit to it - recognizing it as a part of maintenance routine to stay well functioning is really important in my experience. I am pretty bad at pacing myself and managing my own mental and physical wellness, so I am working towards being able to put the brake on early enough so that I don’t crash or skid away into a crash 😂

3) to deal with that feeling of feeling useless, I found that doing things that I wanted to do can help once I have gotten calmer by being in armadillo state for a bit. Getting straight back to work from here for me is extremely difficult, so I start with the combination of taking care of chores that got backed up from busy life and doing what I desire outside of work life. Could be trying a new restaurant, picking up a new hobby or getting back to the hobby that gone on hold due to work life

author: Andy Lawson
content: just taking a break from a mix.. i missed a lot.. the only thing i know is the harder i have worked, the better the industry has been to me.. i started with nothing,  zero $$$$ in my bank account (i did have a photocopied version of the pro tools manual),zero skills, zero training (apart from listening to every song i could)living in a tiny share house room with no windows. but i've slogged and slogged. i've always wanted to be the best at what i do and i carry that with me daily. am i the best, absolutely not. but everyday i go into battle and try to believe i am or want to kick someone else's ass.. it's got me to the point where i bought a house and support my family. i think without that mindset i would have given up on this job years ago. The industry does not play fair and never will, but i firmly believe you can play fair. i've never tried to steal a job from a friend, sneak my way into something. i've just tried to be open and honest with my clients and peers. that's my word vommit on reading above.. lol.... Workhard, Think big, Enjoy! that's all we've got

author: Berlin
content:
I found last year really focusing on a morning routine for myself (self care, if you will) helped me to stay positive. At least I am taking care of myself first and that is all something I can control. Then I can take on the variables and unknowns of the day. Makes for a late start for me now (to which, I'm still adjusting)... but I feel fully ready to face the day every day. Nothing in the back of my mind lingering, letting myself down.. 

Additionally I have let my self imposed work hours go, just freeing myself to be open to the art life as it comes, any hours of the day. Trying to bottle everything into a 9-5 was difficult for me.. why are artists calling me at 9pm? Well.. that's when they are off from their day job and can talk. I took that boundary away for myself and felt some self imposed frustration melt away. Grateful for the calls, emails, texts, DMs.. any hours. Bring it on. 

Both of these changes have helped my attitude and optimism AND HOPE of a future in music and art.. Continuing this on into 2026.

author: Slow Hand
content:
After a decade of performing, touring, and doing production work (and stressing about financial insecurity through much of it) I started an unrelated business with a partner four years ago.

This has turned out to be the right choice for me because it relieves the financial stresses and insecurities and (much like @kidcutler) it allows me to cherry pick the gigs that I want to do.

For a while, making a living on music was a point of pride (or shame when it was not going well). I've always felt a tension between the work that I wanted to create and it's commercial viability. So finding an alternate path to support myself has taken a huge cognitive load off of me and given me the independence to relax and (consequently) better fund my music ventures and enjoy the process again.

author: itaylerner
content: Been with my partner for 9 years and ….yes. lol. This resonates a lot and there’s So much to unpack! Here’s my experience- user experience will vary. The biggest unlocks for me have been not seeing her frustration or lack of enthusiasm as an inconvenient issue that I have to deal with, but rather as a valid fear and a hurt that someone I love is asking for support with. When I get busy and she gets mad, it’s because, historically, my business and fun big opportunities have meant she was going to have a lot of domestic labor and an overwhelming amount of loneliness to deal with. So now when I have a busy time coming up, I meal prep beforehand, I clean the house beforehand, I acknowledge that it’s hard for her, I express tons of gratitude, and I always plan to block out some dedicated alone time for us afterwards. Anything to show that I understand the concessions that she’s making and make my own big efforts to foresee what that means from her and minimize the negative consequences it could have. Maybe even make it something we can both look forward to. Not sure if that’s relevant at all for your circumstances but that’s some of the stuff that’s helped my home life become much more peaceful.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I love this perspective, but to me it shifts the topic from how we feel about ourselves (which is in our control)  to what other people feel about us (which is not).

Sure, someone might have been dealt a poor hand. But is the answer to then just give up, because people will understand? There’s a saying in therapy that goes “it’s not my fault, but it is my responsibility”. I’d rather work to change my poor situation than feel the satisfaction of someone justifying it.

author: Barbara
content:
I have to let you know my first experience with this. Been working on an album that I recorded one year ago. Recording took us 7 days and they still needed to add synths and bass fot some of the songs after that (side note: the production wasn't finished by the time we tracked, so I edited everything I had - 10 songs, none of them with less than 5 minutes. It was the band's first time in the studio, also, and had to edit lots of drums and bass stuff). After doing a first pass, I sent them the multitracks they asked for, to track the rest of their stuff with their producer (a colleague of mine). The next 8 months were spent waiting on their files to start mixing (this was supposed to last 1/2 months, max). When I finally got the files, you have no ideia how messy the project turned out (track names, bounce mistakes, ultrapocessed tracks with artifacts - even the ones we've tracked at the studio before, audible edit points,... all you can imagine going wrong at this point), so it took me a bunch of time to organize everything in a way that I could work with what I've got (going back and forth asking the producer for some files that didn't even get to me or asking if there was the possibility to get some of the tracks dry, without processing or fx - keep this in mind).

Needless to say, when I was ready to start mixing, I was already overwhelmed and tired of it, and I knew I still had a long way to go...

First version took me probably too long to get right (2 months, approx., working on other projects that got scheduled on those 8 months) and I've sent it before I went on a few days vacation.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Came across a stimulating quote recently that I thought was illuminating. The person said the following (paraphrasing):

> "The definition of a nerd is someone who thinks conversation is for peer-reviewing ideas. What do non-nerds think it's for? Negotiating alignment."

Simply based on the way I've framed this question, it's probably pretty clear that I belong to the "peer-reviewing ideas" school of thought (mostly). I love to throw stuff out there, even if I don't believe it. I want to stress test it.

I can certainly appreciate conversation as a tool for aligning people on a belief or course of action, but it's got me wondering about how many of us are playing completely different games when we're having a conversation, and what other games are there? Do y'all think differently?

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s just an entirely different product, and entirely different type of people on the spectrum that make it.

I don’t want to assume too much about any particular software business but I assume you’re building software to solve a problem. There’s a right and a wrong way to do it, and a price to come in at. (These rivets will hold up under this amount of stress up against this material so your plane doesn’t fall out of the sky). With music and production, the goal is a lot more amorphous, especially outside of pure radio pop production (I’ve already beaten that horse dead here.) The concepts of done and value are much harder to define because it’s in the eye of the beholder. 

Then, there’s the specific people. Most people that are in software or data management didn’t grow up going “I WANNA BE IN DATA MANAGEMENT”. They fell in to the field because they had an aptitude for it, were good at numbers, and it was a good way to make money so they can pursue their passion outside their job. With musicians, they specifically ran from that kind of life, the music IS the passion. A guy like cian or Noah could make a factor of 10 time more money in another field, but the emotional value they get from their work supersedes that.

It’s just chalk and cheese.

author: sethearnest
content:
Does a balance need to be struck? Tell the truth of the situation -- a given person's motivation/confidence being or not being undermined will persist either direction over time. They'll soon enough meet the wall of Reality into which every one of us is continually smashed. And their intrinsic level of motivation/confidence will handle it or it won't. 

You tell a 12yo talented niece she can't be a professional singer, and she'll internally respond with either, "Oh...that's sad...I would've loved to do that," or she'll respond with some variation of "Efffffff that...I'm gonna' change the world," and then she might. 99% won't, but that attitude is table stakes for that 1% that we're all shooting for here. 

The latter response will happen no matter *what* is told to a given person with a high level of self-motivation. Giving the truth of the difficulties seems to only help by giving the motivated person more navigational wisdom.

author: kieronmenzies
content: Hey this has been a fun discussion to read through. Just to add one more angle to the mix: most of you have been referring to agency as some kind of positive trait that you either have or you don’t have it — almost commodifying it. What if we think of agency, or the qualities of having agency no matter what term we use, as the norm? As in EVERYONE has it. And whether or not we are able to fulfill those qualities and/or desires is due to limiting factors, whether they are external forces (class system, institutional racism, gender discrimination, war, peer pressure, financial hardship, lack of resources, etc) or internal struggles (fear, self-doubt, depression, addiction, laziness, inner saboteur, etc) or any combination thereof. I know it’s totally idealistic but maybe if we’re able to think of everyone as being just as capable as the next -- instead of an “either-you-got-it-or-you-don’t” kind of way, especially in terms of “agency” which sounds like a corporate buzzword du jour -- then we’d be able to focus on and address the aspects of our societal constructs and daily lives that restrict our opportunities to succeed/work/create/thrive/survive/exist.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
As a former (what I would call pretty high level) athlete, I actually think about this thing very intently with regards to working on records and draw from things from the past life. Mine is more focused on how I want to hear (or rather deeply understand how I'm hearing) every day as close to consistent as possible, given we are human of course.

My 2 cents (which of course is just my experience): 

Some sort of routine before you work. Mine is that I wake up almost exactly at the same time every day, will work out at similar times (if possible), literally eat the same thing basically every day before during the work day, coffee at similar times, have  the same routine when I sit down to start work. Not all of that is possible or useful for everyone, but I think we can all find something that would focus us in a way that's useful and ablet to be put into practice for us.

Truly I find it helps a lot. We are physical beings, how our systems and bodies interact can definitely matter, especially in our ability to be available to the music.

That said, sometimes things happen and you gotta go. You will be tired, stressed, whatever. You have to do excellent work under those conditions too, it might be the most important skill if we are being honest about making a career of this. So training specifically for when you feel rough is definitely something I personally find important.  Which is where physically training helps, it's a way to force yourself into (fake) adversity and train response

@Slow Hand I know you know all this, just my experience

author: hyanrarvey
content:
Yo speaking on what @Nomograph Mastering said a few days about staying cool…we have a producer in and so the whole room is a giant mess (like most studios are when they are locked out) and we sold an amp and we wanted to make profiles/name of it before it went out the door 

So the patchbay is a huge mess and I hooked up all the routing and wasn’t getting signal and I started to lose my cool and got super frustrated, Rick calmed me down and we worked out what problem was (I forgot I was feeding the the amp from the di multed on the patchbay instead of feeding it from the converter to run tones..) and after I got cooled down it clicked on why I wasnmt getting signal.



It’s extremely difficult to not get frustrated when trouble shooting and not get overwhelmed by a full patchbay but if you just take a second and breathe/calm down and start reversing your signal flow you’ll find the culprit and move on




Long story short as an engineer you gotta be the calmest one in the room

author: Zakhiggins
content:
Setting an achievable long term exercise goal and making a plan on how you'll get there is a major key for getting into and keeping you exercising. And doing stuff that isn't boring too.
I've always found doing a little often is way more valuable than doing 1 really intense workout here and there. (this is relevant for progression in any kind of physical activity too, and progression matters because its what will keep you interested long term)
Eating well and sleeping enough is also a major key. I know this is really simple stuff but If you make a habit of these things and stay consistent, you'll notice drastic improvements in physical and mental health, and you won't ever feel like exercise is a chore.

If there's one topic that I actually know a lot about, even down to a deep scientific level, it'd be this sorta stuff, so feel free to hmu with any qs whenever lol

It's funny how often old aphorisms get turned around and stripped of their original meaning.

author: Zack Hames
content: If the alternative is to back home, I’ll try to offer some advice from personal experience. I moved to Richmond, VA for a year, got a job at a hotel doing audio visual. I quit my first commercial/post production gig doing ads full time. It was the worst but I was determined to keep working in music, and try to get integrated in the scene/studio world. It was a serious low for my mental health, the job was terrible, I was struggling and scraping by without any pay off. To make a long story short, I applied for a job back home at a big corporate company with a full time composition/post production gig, on a whim - I didn’t think it would get me anywhere. 3 months later I got the job and went back home after a year. I was out of the music scene back home at this point, and it took another year of reconnecting and working hard on my craft with friends who were willing to let me record their bands for the price  of drums heads and guitar strings, and honestly, those two things combined with some luck put me in a very secure and creative place, now making records for bands again that are paying decently well to boot. I don’t know how far you are in your career/journey, but I’m barely anything and have been recording for 15 years. It took me 5 years out of school to get barely a living wage and working lots of different types of audio jobs while making records, to get to a comfortable place emotionally, creatively, and financially. I’d bet almost anybody in this discord has a very similar story. It takes a long time and like others have said, there’s no one way to get there. Just keep doing you and trying to work on things that you enjoy.

author: ALXCPH
content:
For the kind of chops that your description seems to hint at, i would say it is all about tieing technique to your ears. (Assuming, you can already hum a melody on the spot and are not tone deaf) 

I wouldnt worry too much about theory and super correct technique. 

The best Way to get anywhere on an instrument is by Playing it, and doing in consistently. Set some realistic goals and just get going, vocabulary and technique Will come naturally if you just keep Playing. 

Fuck Playing scales and inversions and all that for now. 
Just go learn a metric ton of songs and melodies and learn to play them together. Do it by Ear. It Will be tough in the beginning, but you Will get very decent quickly if you just do the most important Thing, which is being consistent.

I would reccomend setting a low minimum to do everyday to keep a realistic goal that you can keep, rather than a higher on you miss every now and then. You can always add more practice but it sucks to miss out on it.

Start with song you want to Sound like and then you can slowly branch out when the style become second Nature for you. 

Sadly there are no tricks or hacks or whatever youtube wants you to beleive to get their clicks. Its all about muscle memory and developing your ears together. And not to Sound like 4 bar loop, but consistency, and do it a lot. I cannot stress that enough. ❤️

author: Zach Hughes
content:
That's a great question. Does a balance need to be struck? I think it comes down to what we believe about our role in relation to the people we are working with. To someone who doesn't work much with other people to whom success is largely predicated on their lone creative genius maybe the question of balance is neither here nor there.

However, if you are on a team, are a leader, teacher, or coach suddenly you are on the hook with others and the performance of the group matters. The highest achievement, future funding, drawing in more talent, etc... might all come down to the performance of the group. Would it then be wise to be so laissez-faire about undermining the intrinsic motivation / confidence of others? What if an unintended consequence of that attitude is less actual human connection?

Last thought I had is how do we know the truth of someone else's potential? Fwiw I don't know the answers but this is what's kicking around my head.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Everyone’s body responds differently, but I’ve been lucky enough to come out fairly unscathed with my hearing and mobility. 

As I understand it, it’s less about motion than it is repetitive motion. I was also playing guitar professionally so it kinda mixed up the muscles between that and the trackball. I got hurt when I was doing NOTHING but trackball 110+ hours a week for a few months. We were really burning the candle at both ends for a bit. The interesting thing to me is most people burn out their carpal tunnel) which is pointer finger, but mine was medial (I think) tunnel, which was the pinky, from all the chording on the expert trackball. The overuse inflames the tendon which causes it to rub which causes it to get inflamed which causes it to rub which… the steroid shots, some rest, and a lot of ibuprofen over the next few weeks helped.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Quite a bit.

My learning is less music-focused these days, but I budget a lot of time for self-development and continued study.

Sometimes it's  20 min a day in a technical book that I'm reading. I move slowly and make sure I understand before I move on. It may take two months to complete, but I'm steady with it and I do a little bit most days. It's common for me to transcribe notes from high-density talks that I want to learn from and revisit them often over the span of a week. I'm constantly printing out my notes and reading material so that they're easy to revisit throughout the week.

I'm currently taking a project management course through MIT, which has been great. It's uncommon for me to do formal schooling these days, but this is work related and a direct application to my future capabilities that we thought would be beneficial for the company.

When I buy a new plugin (rare) I set aside time to go through it and turn every knob and try each feature to see what it's capable of. Learning a tool on the spot is a good way to kill the creative flow, so I do the exploration up-front when possible.

Often I'll have ideas for novel ways to use a tool (layering distortion, for example) and I'll set aside two hours to explore it and see what I find.

That said, I think my day-to-day may be quite different from a lot of folks here. My eggs aren't all in the business and pressures of record production, and so I rarely find myself buried in such commitments. I tend to keep "normal" business hours these days and keep a hard separation between my commitments and my leisure.

In fact I'd say that I'm actively structuring my life so that I can retain my leisure and don't find myself overwhelmed with commitments. That's a whole other story, though.

author: Brian Reynolds
content: I love this, I apply this same strategies in my own sessions. Even one today with a new to me, song 1 artist. I like to think about it as making sure they're having fun, are engaged with me and the process. As opposed to avoiding stressors. You said everyone's optimal version or depth of engagement will be different. I like what the OG poster said above about taking time to get to know the artist on a human level. The first 30 mins or hour of a session. I'll just talk about life, stories, and passions. Anything other than the specific music we're there to write. I find this time allows everyone time to acclimate to each other. This time gives me a sense of their personality and how to best assist them to give the best performace they can. And with returning artists time to figure what mood they're in. And how to best direct that. And always ready to adapt my approach as I learn the artist and the song on a deeper level.

author: matthewrederburg
content:
I think about the artistry of house music a lot when I work my small FOH gigs. It’s the question of “when the comparison between this canned music and the live performance is made, what do I want the results to be”

One solution that I love is choosing very benign music. Instrumental jazz, what you might call “wallpaper” music. Great music in it’s own right but chosen because:

1. it’s usually different in genre than the acts on stage. A local band in a small venue shouldn’t have to compete with the sound of the biggest records of the genre, even if everyone in attendance would dig the vibe.

2. Less attention grabbing than the acts on stage. Makes the live music seem big and provides a polite tapering down of energy at the end of the night. Sends the message of “the night isn’t over, but wasn’t the band you came to see the hightlight? Let’s simmer in those good feelings.”

Just a few thoughts about one approach. Not always the move.

author: nachomaquieira
content:
It totally makes sense to hope a new release does well cause it can feel like a big boost for motivation and your everyday life. But putting too much pressure or expectation on it can be really tough later on mental health. Most of the time, music/realeses doesn’t drastically change our lives; it’s more about the connection with the people we create it with and staying in the flow of doing what we love.

Over the years, I’ve learned to ease up on the *what could happen* side of "big projects", and instead focus more on truly connecting with the music and the artist in the most genuine, loving, and positive way I can. That’s what brings out our best work and, in turn, leads to better opportunities in the future: musically, financially, and in terms of personal and professional growth.

author: bobby k

What I’ve been changing the past few years (therapy helped kickstart this) is to pause to ask myself why i would feel this way. There’s basically two options - (1) i care about the song (2) i care about impressing or proving myself. Option one elicits feelings of excitement, confidence, the stuff that’s contagious. The stuff you can lead people with. Option two elicits stress, nerves, uncertainty, things that made me an irritable mess. Sucks the energy out of the room.

Our brains can only really believe one thing at a time and I think we know which one of those options EV’s brain believes.

author: Zack Hames
content: This may be weird advice, but sometimes I just say “sure!” (Or completely disregard depending on context) To certain ideas or mix notes and choose not to address them again. It doesn’t always work but sometimes people just say stuff to say stuff, and they may listen to the mix several times again and get used to how it is and not even want the change later or remember they said anything. I know that may sound insulting but I just dealt with this exact thing, and that did save me a few times. If they brought it up again I tried to meet in the middle. I started experimenting with this once I realized being super honest/straight forward/transparent can actually slow down the process without any benefit. This may apply to more commercial productions where people don’t really want a “no” or a “why not” they just want a yes man and a person to get the job done. I hope that makes sense, I feel like some of the other options you’ve definitely already came up with. Sometimes making your case with the utmost confidence can also work! (Not something I do often but it absolutely can work)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yes, for my needs it absolutely is. Though I can totally understand how it can become a time suck for people who enjoy the feeling of being busy. There's a *lot* of productivity porn out there.

I've been managing a small business for the last 5 years and it's a lot of information to keep track of. Notes, thoughts, ideas, receipts, photos, payroll, reminders, plans, parts, etc. Often I need to recall stuff that happened 8 months ago and that requires me to be meticulous in my organization.

On top of that, I'm ramping up into work with a second company that has the potential to draw on every single skill set and interest that I have. Having the tools to draw disparate connections between my past knowledge and the new ventures with this company could be a huge multiplier for what I can do. It's currently helping me to map out the idea space for this company and really get a big picture of everything that's going on.

I'm a big believer that human memory is fallible and prone to unwitting revisions and mis-recollections that distort events. Even in ways that are benign. Every read is a write. So it's important to unload the important stuff in a place where it won't spoil and distort with time. You could say I'm big on long-term memory and a bit weak on short-term memory.

I'm also a glutton for information, and offloading things and storing them "externally" allows me to unburden myself and not get overwhelmed by it all. I consider a lot of what I do to be trading in information and drawing connections. Some of my long-term personal projects revolve around topics like slow, imperceptible, change and there's simply no way to begin to observe that stuff unless I have rock-solid documentation and data that I can call on twenty years from now.

author: Josh
content:
I’m very late to the convo but this is facts. My brother one day called me during his lunch break at Walmart and he was almost crying because he was so frustrated he couldn’t get enough sales to not work there and he said something along the lines of “I can’t believe people are fine with working here”. And I literally said “Bro, you should be JEALOUS. Imagine how much easier your life would be if you were perfectly content with putting the Mayo in the bag.” 

He hung up on me. 

The next day he goes “Hey man. You’re right. I’m jealous of the people who can Mayo in the bag”. 

And that’s just facts. 

I knew a dude who worked at a really great restaurant as a chef. Not the big chef but one of the chefs. During covid he said “eh I have this crazy passion for cooking but never cook for myself. Why don’t I go sell cars?” And he fucking did it and ended up being the only dude I knew who could make $20k a month selling Toyotas without ever having stimulant dependency in his life. This man was leagues happier after the change mostly because he could finally have Sundays off to watch football.

author: spectrummasters
content: My friend (who I told you attended the mcgilchrist lecture ) and I were debating “equality “on Friday evening , instead of actually mixing his record . Anyhoo , he is v bright ….and currently railing against our societies demand for everything to be equal . I’m still building my understanding of his view , but essentially he was arguing that for things to be said to be equal , they must be quantifiable . And so much of what we are seeking to apply our own perceptions of equality to , ie the human experience and comparisons  between our experiences individually ……are so unquantifiable that the notion of guaranteeing equality is a farce

author: spectrummasters
content: v v interesting.....and presses closer to the nexus of it all than that article i reckon. For some reason, i think a lot about the hypocritical critiques that come from all angles towards "hip-hop" . I know that my friends and artists would be targets of theperspective that todays hip-hop is obsessed with materialism and sexual lyrics......but when you are young and struggling to find opportunities in a city like mine (London) and theres real violence all around you.....the love of a man/woman and a fancy car really can make you feel like youve finally got some control over something in your life in a otherwise hostile environment.......and the same folka doing the criticisng , from where i look at it....they like a bmw/merc/tesla just the same as the rappers they criticise do.......and keep their true feelings close in order to not upset their bosses at the firm in the city.......to get that bag. So a lot of the "theyre all about the money/women ......i dont buy into it. Its a denial of ones own desirous motivations ....remove the plank from your own eye before pointin to the speck in another's ....sort of thing )

author: cy (sigh)
content:
1st thing I'd recommend is listening to the Tape Notes podcast. they interview the artists and producers to break down the processes and stories behind the tracks. 

I got quite a bit of confidence in that respect from listening to those . especially ppl  that come back multiple times. I don't even necessarily listen to everyone's music, I'm often more intwrested in their personal approaches - especially since lost are folk who we'd consider "established"  and what I found to be true for most of them is they split into 2 main camps with most of us dancing between them. 

a) have 0 clue wtf they're going for a lot of the time. kind of going with the flow of whatever is happening /they're feeling in the moment. very similarly to people starting out or me. the approach can vary wildly and a whole concept can be born of something seemingly unimportant at any given moment. 

b) there's an outline that comes to mind early and might give some direction. whether that's thematically or sonically. how tightly they stick to this can vary a lot depending on the artist. 

I think there are many factors that come into play - how good and ready the team they have is might be one of the most important imo. that's both for the creative side and admin side. 

as far answering  your questions as a producer, it depends. 
some artist I work with will literally dream up the whole production and I'm kind of facilitating and bringing it into the real world. others will come with loose ideas and others will show up with absolutely nothing and go off the feeling in the moment. some are more involved than others in the production

your relationship with them is probably the biggest factor in knowing how far you can push their creatively bounderies. 
same artist that dreams up their production usually gives me free range to try whatever I want when the session is over and I've overhauled whole songs.  recently a post-punk ish artist picked up a video game ost /jazz fusion prod I was sketching

author: peterlabberton
content: Guilt not so much, but anxiety—around money—absolutely. I’ve been freelancing full time as an engineer/producer/mixer/drummer for 9 years now, 6 in the Bay Area and now 3 in LA. Easily the first half of my time in the bay was just constant anxiety about how I’ll pay rent/will I work/blah blah. Then things got more solid and I could take my foot off the gas a bit. Was able to relax and feel confident I could make ends meet. Then I blew it all up and moved to LA to start over again! Ha. Not *really* start over again 100% since I had a lot more experience and a tiny bit of a track record, but I’m only now beginning to feel that corner turning again, just a bit. I definitely feel that for me, those feelings correlate to how comfortable I am on, I guess you’d say, the business side and how it’s working out. Creatively I feel like taking time away is always helpful.

author: rae
content:
Late to the convo but I used to feel guilty about hanging out with people over working and I too get panic attacks (mainly from stress) so I’m sorry to hear about that and I’m happy to recommend some strategies if you need as I’ve kept mine at bay for almost a year now 🙂 

Going back to the first topic, I use notebooks and diaries to structure my days so I don’t feel guilty when I’m not working. For example, if I’ve agreed to go out with friends on Saturday night and I want to prioritise that, then I’ll figure out how much work I’ll realistically have to do in the day and either set timers for myself to stick to schedule or just follow what I outlined for myself. I find once I’ve achieved something it’s like hanging out with my mates is a reward now for the hard work I put in earlier - and it’s easier to disconnect from the work for a bit and have a good time - hope this helps!

author: skinnybreakfast
content:
Sorry for the book incoming. But this is plaguing my mind. Has there been an in-depth discussion on live or in discord yet about musicians on tiktok? 

It's a crazy scene of selling your creative soul for 1 minute of attempting to go viral. and then if you do get a popular video, whatever that one was - that is now your thing... singing into a trash can doing RHCP covers... ok, now do another 100 of those.  I see so much talent on there, genuine talent and artists who have worked hard on their craft getting 10 views due to the algo... once the algo has tried your vid on a few people and it didn't stick the vid is dead... so it's totally hit and miss based on your first small sample of viewers.

I see this having a huge impact in many ways. On the plus - you are getting exposure to incredible new ideas, skills, trends, methods for being creative... on the negative it's demotivating to the nth degree, and cheapening the creative process, in my opinion.

Matt and Jon recently talked about track lengths getting shorter and shorter, now 2 minutes is the normal. Partly due to the attention span of people... well what is this going to do... 1 minute pop tracks incoming? Just gimme the hook in 30 seconds and let's move on please. :p. How can we get young people to lay on the floor and listen to 10 minute vinyl tracks again? In my opinion humanity NEEDS this :)) 

I also swear I've heard the influence of trending memes from tiktok coming through in music in the charts, but cannot really back this up.

What's everyone else's thoughts? I have a friend in LA who says everyone has gone crazy there for tiktok fame? 😛

author: Barbara
content:
They came back with 10 PAGES of comments, with stuff regarding other takes we might had (I forgot to mention, but it was a deal that once I've sent the files for them to continue production, every take and edit was correct and accepted by all of them, in order to commit and make decisions... specially, because it was an edit nightmare, but mostly because I knew they weren't experient and it would be hard to finish anything if we kept having too many options to chose from - which we hadn't. That was indeed the most polished takes and performance they had, and it still needed A LOT of care), a list of reference tracks that wasn't even close in anything to what we had or could ever have, and me wanting not to jump in again on all of that. And during this, I had other people hearing my mix (colleagues) that were harsh on the way they gave feedback - not criticising, I knew it was shite, but I think it was the right thing at the wrong time for me.

At this point, I was struggling so bad with imposter syndrome, I was seriously considering quitting and getting the blues about the process, not happy with the result but not sure how I could do any better. And yes, I was working on other stuff, but this project was sucking all my energy and mood.
Feeling like a fraud and a failure. There is no sugar coating it.
But most of all, I wanted to make it work for the band. I wanted to give them my best, and wanted really hard that my best could be the best for them. So I kept going, and entered into it. 

Version 2... 7 pages of comments, all on different stuff that I thought we already nailed on the first version, since there was absolutely no comment on those things before... 

Oh, by the way, by this time, I was still waiting on some dry tracks from the producer, to make moves that the band asked for on the first version review.

author: austenballard
content:
Speaking as someone who moved to the US, there are a lot of things that will make you miss Europe sorely. Mainly quality of life things, especially if you're moving to Texas (although ATX is not so bad)

First, as people have mentioned, this country is massive. Everything is disproportionately large and far away. You will drive everywhere, which as a German you might not have an issue with, but it gets annoying when you want to pop over to the corner store to grab something and then you remember that doesn't exist, and then you're driving 30 minutes on the highway to the supermarket just to get two things. Normal errands will take you ridiculous amounts of time if you're not in a dense city, particularly east coast cities (NYC ftw)

Next, there's the increasingly Kafkaesque nature of every commercial interaction in the US. People are generally not paid enough relative to their cost of living and are constantly stressed by student debt, credit card debt, auto debt, mortgage debt (if they're lucky enough), etc. As a result, those in many public-facing service jobs do not do their jobs very well. Sorting out a minor problem can easily involve hours of slogging through telephone menus and talking to service reps who can't really help you. An example is it recently took me over a month and 20+ calls to 4 different places to switch my health insurance, which is supposed to take a week at most through an internet portal (Healthcare.gov)

I’ve never been but I hope to go as soon as I can. Seems like you’ve got to get out of the US to appreciate the history, architecture, food, culture, etc.

I have ADHD and unhinged anxiety. So I have all of these little things I do to make sure I don’t implode on a daily basis.

author: ehutton21
content:
To @Rollmottle’s point, maybe I can bridge this gap here, but from the perspective of someone dealing with mental health issues, it’s a fine line between empowerment and complete lack of accountability. There are ways of accommodating people that empower them, and that’s important. Part of that accommodation looks like recognizing that when someone has a really bad go, they’re going to struggle to assimilate themselves into the rest of society some days. But on the flip side, people with mental health issues are people. My bipolar ass can drive a car—doesn’t mean I get to drive off the road and cause collisions whenever I’d like, and even at my worst I’m capable of knowing that. 

Anxiety is difficult in that you often border on delusions—panic attacks are delusions about experiencing serious medical issues for a huge swath of people, and while that can make it difficult to do things like eat on a regular basis, I have to be mindful that having a stringent routine that keeps my triggers at bay is critical.

author: spectrummasters

People need to know this stuff it’s vital to our quality of life experience . In my kitchen I alternate smooth fm (70s/80s classics for the sonics ) or birdsong , for the stress relief . author: peterlabberton
content: Trying to add to things and make a broader point without stepping in shit… I think I probably often come off as a Luddite, but I am truly not at all. I’ve always been a tech geek at heart. But I do deeply feel a resistance to tech that feels foisted on us, the general public, as it so often is just money making wrapped in the veneer of “progress” (or connection or whatever). Not said in this context with a political motivation, but, in capitalism we just have these things popping up all the time with no regard to whether we *want* them or whether they will make our lives *actually better*. And no, I don’t think an app that streamlines you getting your dog groomed or whatever is actually a substantive improvement in human life. So much stuff we have now actually makes us *less* happy and fulfilled, and so I always want to push back on the next new thing having had the hindsight of how these products have played out over the last two decades. (Thus ends a half-baked tech screed—sorry y’all.)

author: Deleted User
content:
when we think of how language and words get created out of necessity, we can also use that to work our way back and analyze why certain words become popular or lost its use over time. especially with internet, language started driving a good part of pop culture. we don’t want the words to limit our expressions, we want words to enable more articulate expressions and thinking -> both are happening from what I see. 

Why does the new generation feel the need to minimize and maximize everything? Why can’t we spend our effort into exploring everything in between? 

Do everything in between come with labels or do they become lengthy sentences and paragraphs? 

I think the answer to all of this is complexity of life that us humans brought onto ourselves. That is the cycle of “why older generation can’t understand newer generations”

older generations make the world “better” - (technologies and advancement of civilization & cultural understanding ) for the new generation. But what this “better” comes with many times though, is complicated soup of mess. This causes overload in young people’s minds trying to make sense of this world. Many or most don’t have the patience to keep on trying to explore the nuances in between. Or can’t afford to take the time / invest the energy to do so. I believe the lack of dimensions in the new generation’s language is a product of this. 

@NoahNeedleman said older, less nuanced in opinion & younger, less nuanced in language. I believe both are true for both younger and older people *if they ended up giving up trying to dig deeper to explore and ponder on “everything in between”*. I don’t think age has anything to do with it. It’s just that the disparities between those who had the patience for nuance vs those who gave up trying become more apparent as people get older.

author: Deleted User

I also want to mention something I learned about recently, and that is borderline intellectual functioning. People with IQ between 71-84 are not categorized as disabled and you won’t notice them in everyday life, but it can be as common as 1 out of 7 people. They won’t be able to get a disability check, but will have harder time living than others with average or higher intelligence. 

It gave me a new perspective on why I can’t seem to communicate with or understand certain people, and that it needs to be approached with empathy whenever possible. 

+ poverty can affect people’s brain development. not only from the lack of education but the stress that goes on in the household due to poverty can affect children’s brain development. Truly unfortunate viscous cycle…

author: Deleted User
content:
Whether that was the best use of the money at the time is probably a different question than whether you made a good investment. 

Comparing real estate and stock is probably apples to oranges. Yes, you get some amount of volatility that could potentially generate more returns in a shorter period of time - but that also means more risk.

I don’t know if you already own/trade stocks, but I would say it’s likely going to be more stressful than owning a home… Stock market isn’t for everyone. I certainly don’t think it is for me with the way my mind works. I know a few people whom their overall lives would be better off if they just invested in MMF, index funds and bonds rather than stock. Just because how anxiety inducing it is and there’s so much to keep up with at all times… If you’re not doing that or have the stock managed by someone who does that, it’s not really much different from gambling. 

Another thing, there’s probably always another investment that could have made more money- but there’s always another investment that could have made more loss. It’s not worth dwelling on because there is no end to it. So don’t beat yourself up about this. As others have said, if you have tenants paying rent then you are still building equity over time

My gf is probably closer to a 0 here and she is generally happier than I am and very successful in her career. I think I'd rather crank the slider closer to zero the older I get.

author: Matt Huber
content:
So, first of all, thanks to the buds here who appreciate what I’ve posted in the past.

Second of all, my thoughts on this:
 
I have a personal rule that I will NOT post anything that feels like EFFORT or out of a motivation to game the algo. If I’m “making content” and notice that I’m doing so out of a place that is less than genuine, I will just delete and move on. 

For me, the “mix tips” thing came out of a sincere place of excitement and passion. I would, as a growing mix engineer, stumble upon something that excited me, and I would find myself wanting to turn around to the people in the room to share…well, there’s almost never anyone in the room with me. So, I channeled that passion and excitement in a genuine way to share with the small community of mixers, mastering engineers and producers that I knew on IG. 

At the beginning of my career on to the middle of my career, that became a very fruitful source of business for me - people who followed me on IG, who enjoyed my posts, and began to view me as someone who MIGHT know a thing or two about mixing. 

As my career has developed and my clientele has growing, that has become less important, but it was absolutely pivotal in helping me build a deep bench of great clients, both indie and signed. 

But…I NEVER did it for that reason. It was always (and continues to be) a genuine result of my passion for what I do.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
This video brought to mind a highlight from a recent read: "When you’re invested in a goal, being doubted by experts is a threat. They may be credible, but since they don’t recognize your potential, they’re not coaches who will help you improve. Their disbelief quickly becomes your insecurity. It shatters your confidence and stifles your growth. That’s a self-fulfilling prophecy. But the research suggests that when they come from an uninformed audience, low expectations can become a self-negating prophecy. You’re motivated to shatter their confidence that you won’t succeed. Samir calls it the underdog effect." - Adam Grant, *Hidden Potential*

Also related are the concepts of the Pygmalion and the Golem effect in social psychology. Where low / high expectations for students / beginners can become self fulfilling prophecies. Begs the question how do you find the balance between being honest / truthful with folks just starting out without significantly undermining their intrinsic motivation and confidence?

author: Zach Hughes

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: Without telling the story about two years ago I had my first “bad” client. They were in the middle of building a house (unknown to me) and decided this would be a great time to manage that project but also make a record with me. Because I was under the impression that studios were financially out of reach for this person, I worked at half my usual rate and allowed them to give me a small deposit to start working together. MY MISTAKE.  Every time they came to the studio they were stressed out and unfocused. I did my best to make their home recordings sound great but there was very little good communication and it ended up that when I sent a mix over, I got a 8 paragraph dump about how nothing is working out, the mix was nothing they would ever release, then proceeded to call me a bunch of names - just taking out all their frustration on me. I zipped up all the work I had done so far and sent it over saying I think it’s best if we went our separate ways, you can do what you like with what we’ve done so far - I don’t want any credits at all. Since then it’s motivated me to make sure that I am following my process and OVERcommunicating every step of the way to be sure there’s no confusion about the work I do with clients. I learned that this former client bad mouthed me to a few artists and I lost some work because of it. Eventually work got back to normal and it’s been steady rocking ever since. The memory of how I felt motivated me everyday to be better than the day before, no joke - I know there’s going to be bad days here and there but I’ll be damned if I ever let someone take advantage of me like that again.

author: Deleted User
content:
Thank you all for chiming in on this, it really got me thinking! I took some time to dig deeper into my uncomfort with this topic and I think it’s really just about the concept of a “personality trait”. Maybe we can jam a little on it.

I had this example in mind:
Let’s say we meet someone for the first time and while we’re interacting I gather that this person seems like a “happy person”, they’re smiling, giving off warm vibes and are kind. We keep on meeting this person and the experience repeats itself. So the more we meet, the more our idea that this person must be a “happy person” solidifies. We know of course that this is an abstraction and that the person is probably going to be sad, angry, etc. at times. 

Now let’s say we think, man I really liked this person they are so easy to deal with, I enjoyed every bit of our interaction. I wish more people would be like that! And there you go. Now you are set to figure out all the details about happiness, the factors that make a “happy person” a “happy person”. The warmness, the kindness etc. and help people be more happy. 

Now you’re really digging into it, you start making videos, writing blogs going out to teach happiness. People are really digging it and you feel like you’re doing good for the world. So the concept is in everyone’s mind happiness is what we should strive for and whoever is not happy enough yet just needs to try harder. Suddenly you’re watching the news and you hear more and more people are getting symptoms of depression, stress and anxiety. And you think to yourself wow how did that happen? I thought I was making   the world a better place. 

And I think that’s what’s happening with a lot of these concepts that once they get institutionalized or gain popularity they somewhat lose their initial intent and can even have a rebounding effect. I mean we can see it going that way with a lot of different trends like mindfulness, health awareness, the work life balance etc.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
So many great responses to this.

I feel like every time I’m overwhelmed and take a deep breath to ground myself, Imm embracing some sort of letting go.

In any given moment I feel something in my mind that draws me towards holding it at the forefront. Every time I let go and allow myself to experience the present, it’s a process of surrendering in itself.

Perhaps like curling a dumbell, the more you let go in all those micromoments, the bigger the ‘present’ muscle in your brain strengthens.

Big moments of surrender are a fantastic way of resetting into yourself, and the micro moments of surrender are how one prolongs that return to self, even when in the crashing waves of life as it ebbs and flows.

That’s my experience^ So I’d say - Trying to embrace surrender all together has been a must for me to get to a place to start really living life in the now.

author: spectrummasters
content:
For sure , I completely agree with you that weight should be given to the apparent findings of rigorous work . Absolutely. I also think it is a disservice to all of us if people are discouraged to approach unpopular ideas and ask questions about them for fear of mockery . Or that newcomers simply accept dogma of the day . That is anti science . Our greatest scientific discoveries usually shatter the pre existing concencus view (for the benefit of all ) Newtonian physics gives way to relativity, classic physics to quantum etc . 
As you will know Cian , science is not about proving  things with absolute certainty it deals in probabilities . 
Science works to bring us to a place where we can say p< 0.05 . So imho we shouldn’t loosely  present science as absolute and unchanging truths in service of quietening and/ or deriding people and/or their ideas . 
Imho what is being missed in so doing is that it is those who dare to challenge dogma,  who challenge and constantly review empirical evidence that bring us the new discoveries . My point is less about discrediting null tests and more about celebrating people who dare to challenge dogma . And that science is also in support of those people . If young people / newcomers are to chase a few rabbit holes and cul de sacs for the will of exploration and finding things out for themselves , who would deny them that ? Those who probably did much the same thing themselves at the start of their journey into audio ? It certainly appears to be true that under observation and current technology the daws sum. Yet we are also at a moment in science where mathematicians are suggesting our reality may only be an avatar and time as a concept is outdated . In mind of these leading edges of scientific thought someone as clever as Jon challenging a consensus on nulling may or may not be genius . But laughing at or dismissing his and Aaron’s and many others sense on it …..doesn’t serve any of us imho .

It’s crazy how important living in the present moment is for feeling optimistic and grateful. You made a really important point here.
If I look at my own situation today, I could totally make your words my own. My family is doing well, and I’m about to finish a mix of a reasonably good song. Still, I can’t help thinking about the future and feeling kind of depressed and worried. Will the phone ring? Will I get to work on music that really resonates with me? Will I be able to provide for and take care of my family? How can I improve my skills? I feel like my work isn’t good enough, etc.
Music can be really tough on mental health, and not living in the present—constantly anticipating dark scenarios—is probably the worst enemy.

content: Hey guys, so I wear a lot of different hats in my day to day, as I'm sure a lot of you do. Does anyone else experience a kind of uncertainty/mild anxiety about their work that might derive from the fact that you're not really specialized in a certain area? I feel like I'm not always as excited or confident about getting into a certain task not only because I know i'm not very good at it yet (which i know is all relative, I could still be exactly what someone else needs for something), but also because I know others are out there, sometimes in my personal circle, who are much better? For a little added detail, my fulltime career is as a voice actor, but I love mixing, and sometimes I produce some baby artists, engineer ADR and video game/commercial voiceover. This week i was asked to dialog edit an animated film, I have to comp vocals for someone's song, and there's always a litany of othere stuff, none of which I ever feel prepared to do so the work usually takes longer than I know it should. Maybe the answer is simply to stop trying to be everything to everyone, but honestly I'm terrified to put all my eggs into the voiceover basket even though it's what I've got the most momentum with.
